expanded_description: What happens to a firm's costs when it can change all of its inputs? In the long run, nothing is fixed—firms can build new factories, invest in more machinery, and adjust every aspect of production. This flexibility fundamentally changes how costs behave. Instead of being constrained by fixed inputs, firms can choose the optimal scale of operation. The long-run analysis reveals whether firms experience economies of scale (falling average costs as output increases) or diseconomies of scale (rising average costs). These concepts explain why some industries are dominated by large firms while others support many small businesses, and why some industries naturally tend toward monopoly while others remain competitive.

core_concept.principle: In the long run, all inputs are variable. There are no fixed costs—all costs are variable. The long-run average cost (LRAC) curve shows the lowest possible average cost of producing any output level when the firm can choose any scale of operation. (1) Economies of scale: Occur when long-run average cost falls as output increases. Causes: specialization, division of labor, bulk buying, technological factors, learning effects. (2) Diseconomies of scale: Occur when long-run average cost rises as output increases. Causes: coordination problems, communication difficulties, bureaucratic inefficiency, principal-agent problems. (3) Constant returns to scale: Occur when long-run average cost is constant as output increases. (4) The LRAC curve is typically U-shaped, falling due to economies of scale, then rising due to diseconomies of scale. (5) The relationship between short-run and long-run cost curves: The LRAC curve is the envelope of all possible short-run average total cost (SRATC) curves. Each SRATC curve represents a different plant size. The firm chooses the plant size that minimizes cost for its desired output. (6) Minimum efficient scale (MES): The smallest output level at which long-run average cost is minimized. Industries with high MES relative to market demand tend toward oligopoly or monopoly.
core_concept.explanation: Think of a restaurant chain. A small restaurant might have high average costs because it can't buy in bulk or afford specialized equipment. As it grows to a medium size, average costs fall—it can negotiate better prices, use more efficient ovens, and have specialized staff. That's economies of scale. But if it becomes a massive global chain, average costs might start rising again—coordination becomes difficult, communication breaks down, and bureaucracy slows decisions. That's diseconomies of scale. The long-run average cost curve captures this pattern.

sections.introduction: What happens to a firm's costs when it can change all of its inputs? In the long run, nothing is fixed—firms can build new factories, invest in more machinery, and adjust every aspect of production. This flexibility fundamentally changes how costs behave. Instead of being constrained by fixed inputs, firms can choose the optimal scale of operation. The long-run analysis reveals whether firms experience economies of scale (falling average costs as output increases) or diseconomies of scale (rising average costs). These concepts explain why some industries are dominated by large firms while others support many small businesses, and why some industries naturally tend toward monopoly while others remain competitive.

key_concept.definition: In the long run, all inputs are variable, so there are no fixed costs. The firm can choose any combination of inputs and any scale of operation. (1) Long-run average cost (LRAC or LATC): The curve showing the lowest possible average cost of producing each output level when the firm can choose the optimal plant size. It is U-shaped for many industries. (2) Economies of scale: Occur when LRAC falls as output increases. Average cost decreases with scale. (3) Diseconomies of scale: Occur when LRAC rises as output increases. Average cost increases with scale. (4) Constant returns to scale: Occur when LRAC is constant as output increases. Average cost does not change with scale. (5) Sources of economies of scale: (a) Specialization and division of labor—workers become more efficient at specific tasks. (b) Technological factors—larger scale allows use of more efficient machinery. (c) Bulk buying—larger firms get discounts on inputs. (d) Learning effects—experience reduces costs over time. (e) Network effects—value increases with scale for some products. (6) Sources of diseconomies of scale: (a) Coordination problems—larger organizations are harder to manage. (b) Communication difficulties—information gets distorted. (c) Bureaucracy—rules and procedures slow decisions. (d) Principal-agent problems—workers may not share firm's goals. (7) Relationship to short-run curves: The LRAC curve is the envelope of all possible short-run average total cost (SRATC) curves. Each SRATC curve represents a different plant size. At any output, the firm chooses the plant size that gives the lowest average cost. (8) Minimum efficient scale (MES): The smallest output at which LRAC reaches its minimum. Industries where MES is large relative to market demand tend to have few firms (oligopoly or natural monopoly).
key_concept.context: The distinction between short-run and long-run costs was developed by Alfred Marshall and later refined by economists like Jacob Viner. The concept of economies of scale is crucial for understanding market structure, international trade, and industrial policy. It explains why some industries (like automobile manufacturing) are dominated by large firms, while others (like hair salons) support many small businesses. It also underlies the concept of natural monopoly—where one firm can serve the entire market at lower cost than multiple firms. In AP Microeconomics, understanding long-run costs is essential for analyzing firm behavior in different market structures and for welfare analysis.

classifications.behavior: Economies of scale occur when increasing all inputs proportionally leads to a more than proportional increase in output, causing average cost to fall. This is common in industries with high fixed costs or significant specialization opportunities. As firms grow, they can: (1) Divide labor into specialized tasks, increasing productivity. (2) Invest in larger, more efficient machinery that small-scale production couldn't justify. (3) Negotiate lower prices from suppliers through bulk purchasing. (4) Spread research and development costs over more units. (5) Benefit from learning effects—experience reduces costs. Industries with strong economies of scale tend toward concentration—fewer, larger firms because large firms have cost advantages. Examples: automobile manufacturing, semiconductor fabrication, airlines (hub-and-spoke systems). The minimum efficient scale in these industries is large relative to market size.

image.caption: Figure 4.5.4: Economies of scale—average cost falls as output increases.

examples.explanation: A car factory has huge fixed costs for assembly lines and equipment. Spreading these over more vehicles lowers average cost. A plant producing 200,000 cars per year has much lower average cost than one producing 20,000.
Costco and Sam's Club achieve economies of scale through bulk purchasing and large-format stores, lowering average cost per item sold.

classifications.behavior: Diseconomies of scale occur when increasing all inputs proportionally leads to a less than proportional increase in output, causing average cost to rise. This typically happens in very large organizations due to management and coordination challenges. As firms become enormous: (1) Communication becomes difficult—messages get distorted as they pass through layers of management. (2) Coordination costs rise—it's harder to align different divisions and departments. (3) Bureaucracy grows—rules and procedures slow decision-making and innovation. (4) Principal-agent problems emerge—workers and managers may pursue their own interests rather than the firm's. (5) Motivation and morale can decline in impersonal large organizations. Diseconomies of scale put an upper limit on firm size—beyond some point, getting larger actually increases average cost. This helps explain why even in industries with economies of scale, firms don't grow infinitely large.

image.caption: Figure 4.5.5: Diseconomies of scale—average cost rises as output increases.

examples.explanation: As companies grow to massive size, they often become bureaucratic and slow-moving. Decision-making gets bogged down, and average costs may rise. This is why some large firms break into smaller divisions.
Very large government departments often experience diseconomies of scale—inefficiency, poor coordination, and rising per-unit costs as they grow.

classifications.behavior: Constant returns to scale occur when increasing all inputs proportionally leads to an exactly proportional increase in output, so average cost remains constant. This often happens in the middle range of output, after economies of scale are exhausted but before diseconomies begin. In this region, firm size does not affect average cost—small and large firms can be equally efficient. This allows many firms of different sizes to coexist in an industry. Constant returns are common in industries where production can be easily replicated—adding another factory identical to the first produces the same average cost. The range of constant returns varies by industry; some industries have a broad flat region, others have a narrow range or even a single point of minimum efficient scale.

image.caption: Figure 4.5.6: Constant returns to scale—average cost constant as output increases.

examples.explanation: A successful restaurant format can be replicated. Each new location has similar costs, so average cost is constant across many locations—constant returns to scale.
Law firms or consulting firms can add more partners and associates, with each new team operating similarly, leading to constant returns over a range.

classifications.behavior: Minimum efficient scale (MES) is the smallest output level at which long-run average cost reaches its minimum. It is a crucial concept for understanding market structure. If MES is small relative to total market demand, many firms can operate efficiently, and the industry will tend to be competitive (e.g., restaurants, hair salons). If MES is large relative to market demand, only a few firms can reach efficient scale, leading to oligopoly or even natural monopoly (e.g., aircraft manufacturing, local utilities). The shape of the LRAC curve around MES also matters: if the curve is flat near MES, firms can be somewhat smaller and still be nearly efficient; if the curve rises sharply below MES, small firms are at a severe cost disadvantage. Policymakers consider MES when evaluating mergers and antitrust issues.

image.alt: LRAC curve with MES marked at minimum point
image.caption: Figure 4.5.7: Minimum efficient scale is the smallest output achieving minimum LRAC.

examples.explanation: In beer production, MES is quite large due to economies of scale in brewing and distribution. This explains why the industry is dominated by a few large firms, though craft breweries survive in niche markets.
Local bakeries have relatively small MES, allowing many small businesses to coexist with large industrial bakeries.

principles.principle: The LRAC Curve Is the Envelope of SRATC Curves
principles.statement: The long-run average cost curve is derived from the firm's short-run average total cost curves for different plant sizes. Each SRATC curve represents a different scale of operation (different level of fixed inputs). In the long run, the firm can choose any plant size. For any given output, the firm will choose the plant size that minimizes average cost. The LRAC curve connects these minimum-cost points, forming an envelope around the SRATC curves. The LRAC touches each SRATC curve at exactly one point—the output where that plant size is optimal. At all other outputs, that plant size would have higher average cost than the optimal size. This relationship explains why LRAC is always below or tangent to SRATC curves—never above. Understanding this helps firms make long-run investment decisions about plant size and helps economists analyze industry structure.
principles.application: When planning long-run expansion, a firm should consider the LRAC curve to choose the optimal plant size for its target output. The firm will operate on the SRATC curve for that plant size in the short run, but can move to a different curve in the long run.
principles.example: A factory considering expanding from 100,000 units to 200,000 units should compare the average cost at 200,000 using its current plant (moving along its SRATC) versus building a new plant designed for 200,000 units (a different SRATC). The LRAC shows the lowest possible cost.

image.alt: Multiple SRATC curves with LRAC as envelope touching each at one point
image.caption: Figure 4.5.8: LRAC is the envelope of all possible SRATC curves.

principles.principle: Returns to Scale Differ from Diminishing Returns
principles.statement: It's crucial to distinguish between returns to scale (long-run concept) and diminishing returns (short-run concept). Diminishing returns refers to what happens when adding variable inputs to fixed inputs—it's a short-run phenomenon. Returns to scale refers to what happens when all inputs are increased proportionally—it's a long-run concept. A firm can experience both: in the short run, it faces diminishing returns to labor as it adds workers to a fixed factory; in the long run, it might experience economies of scale as it builds larger factories and hires proportionally more workers. The two concepts are related but distinct. Diminishing returns causes short-run cost curves to slope upward; returns to scale determines the shape of the long-run average cost curve. Understanding this distinction is essential for correctly analyzing firm behavior in different time horizons.
principles.application: When analyzing costs, always specify whether you're in the short run or long run. Short-run cost increases are due to diminishing returns; long-run cost patterns are due to returns to scale. Use the correct concept for the time frame.
principles.example: A factory in the short run faces rising marginal cost due to diminishing returns—adding workers to a fixed factory eventually yields smaller output increases. In the long run, it might build a second factory and experience constant or increasing returns to scale.

image.alt: Side-by-side: diminishing returns (short run) and returns to scale (long run)
image.caption: Figure 4.5.9: Diminishing returns (short run) vs. returns to scale (long run).

principles.principle: Minimum Efficient Scale Determines Market Structure
principles.statement: The minimum efficient scale (MES) relative to market demand is a key determinant of market structure. When MES is small compared to total market demand, many firms can achieve efficient scale, leading to a competitive industry with many firms. When MES is large relative to market demand, only a few firms can reach efficient scale, leading to oligopoly or even natural monopoly. The shape of the LRAC curve also matters: if the curve is flat over a wide range, firms of various sizes can coexist; if the curve rises sharply below MES, small firms are at a severe disadvantage. This relationship explains why some industries naturally concentrate while others remain fragmented. It also guides antitrust policy—mergers that create firms significantly larger than MES might not generate efficiency gains and could harm competition.
principles.application: To predict industry structure, estimate MES relative to market size. If MES is 10% of the market, the industry could support up to 10 efficient firms. If MES is 50% of the market, the industry will likely be an oligopoly or duopoly.
principles.example: In automobile manufacturing, MES is estimated at several hundred thousand vehicles per year. With global demand in the tens of millions, the industry can support dozens of firms—but not thousands. In local garbage collection, MES might be large enough that one firm can serve an entire city efficiently, leading to natural monopoly.

image.alt: Comparison: small MES → many firms, large MES → few firms
image.caption: Figure 4.5.10: Minimum efficient scale relative to market size determines industry structure.

worked_examples.title: Constructing LRAC from SRATC Curves

image.alt: Three SRATC curves for different plant sizes
image.caption: Figure 4.5.11: Construct the LRAC curve from given SRATC curves.

worked_examples.problem:
A firm has three possible plant sizes with the following short-run average total cost curves:
Small plant: $SRATC_S = 100/Q + 5 + 0.01Q$
Medium plant: $SRATC_M = 200/Q + 4 + 0.005Q$
Large plant: $SRATC_L = 400/Q + 3 + 0.002Q$
a) Calculate the average cost for each plant at outputs of 100, 200, 300, 400, and 500 units.
b) For each output, determine which plant gives the lowest average cost.
c) Sketch the LRAC curve.
d) What is the approximate minimum efficient scale?

step_by_step.explanation: LRAC values: Q=100:6.5, Q=200:5.4, Q=300:4.93, Q=400:4.8, Q=500:4.8. LRAC falls to Q=400, then constant. Minimum efficient scale is around Q=400.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) See calculations. b) Q=100: medium; Q=200-500: large. c) LRAC falls then flattens. d) MES ≈ 400 units.
worked_examples.concept_applied: LRAC is constructed by taking the lowest SRATC at each output. MES is where LRAC reaches minimum.

worked_examples.title: Identifying Returns to Scale

image.caption: Figure 4.5.12: Determine returns to scale from production data.

worked_examples.problem:
A firm's production function shows the following output for different combinations of labor and capital (both variable in long run):
1 unit L, 1 unit K → 100 units output
2 units L, 2 units K → 220 units output
3 units L, 3 units K → 360 units output
4 units L, 4 units K → 480 units output
5 units L, 5 units K → 580 units output
a) Determine if the firm experiences increasing, constant, or decreasing returns to scale.
b) What does this imply about the shape of the LRAC curve?
c) If input prices are $\$10$ per unit for both L and K, calculate long-run average cost at each scale.
d) At what scale does LRAC minimize?

step_by_step.explanation:
Compare output increases to input increases:
1→2 units: inputs double (100%), output increases from 100 to 220 (120%) → more than proportional → increasing returns
2→3 units: inputs increase 50%, output from 220 to 360 (64%) → more than proportional → increasing returns
3→4 units: inputs increase 33%, output from 360 to 480 (33%) → exactly proportional → constant returns
4→5 units: inputs increase 25%, output from 480 to 580 (21%) → less than proportional → decreasing returns
Increasing returns → LRAC falling. Constant returns → LRAC flat. Decreasing returns → LRAC rising. So LRAC should fall from 100-360, be flat around 360-480, then rise after 480.
LRAC minimizes at 360-480 units (0.167). Minimum efficient scale is around 360 units.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Increasing returns at low scales, constant at medium, decreasing at high. b) LRAC falls, flattens, then rises (U-shaped). c) LRAC: 0.20, 0.182, 0.167, 0.167, 0.172. d) Minimum at 360-480 units.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Returns to scale determine the shape of LRAC. Increasing returns → falling LRAC, constant returns → flat LRAC, decreasing returns → rising LRAC.

worked_examples.title: Natural Monopoly Analysis

image.caption: Figure 4.5.13: Determine if this industry is a natural monopoly.

worked_examples.problem:
An industry has the following long-run average cost curve: $LRAC = 1000/Q + 2$. Market demand is $Q = 500 - 10P$.
a) What is the shape of the LRAC curve? Does it exhibit economies of scale?
b) Calculate LRAC at outputs of 100, 200, 300, 400, and 500.
c) If one firm serves the entire market, what price would it need to charge to cover its costs at the market-clearing quantity?
d) If two firms split the market equally, what would be each firm's average cost?
e) Is this a natural monopoly? Explain.

step_by_step.explanation: $LRAC = 1000/Q + 2$. As Q increases, 1000/Q decreases, so LRAC continuously declines. This means economies of scale exist at all output levels—LRAC never rises.

Find market-clearing quantity and price from demand: $Q = 500 - 10P$. Also need to find where demand intersects LRAC? Actually, we need the quantity where market demand equals LRAC pricing. At equilibrium, price would need to cover LRAC. If one firm produces where demand equals LRAC, we solve $P = 1000/Q + 2$ and $Q = 500 - 10P$. Substitute: $Q = 500 - 10(1000/Q + 2)$ → $Q = 500 - 10000/Q - 20$ → $Q + 10000/Q = 480$ → multiply by Q: $Q^2 - 480Q + 10000 = 0$. Solve: $Q = [480 ± √(230400 - 40000)]/2 = [480 ± √190400]/2 = [480 ± 436.4]/2$. Positive solution: $(480 + 436.4)/2 = 458.2$. Price = $1000/458.2 + 2 = 2.18 + 2 = 4.18$.
Each firm produces half: Q ≈ 229. Each firm's LRAC = $1000/229 + 2 = 4.37 + 2 = 6.37$. Average cost is much higher than with one firm (4.18).

Yes, this is a natural monopoly because one firm can produce at lower average cost ($4.18) than two firms ($6.37). The LRAC declines over the entire range of market demand, so a single firm is more efficient.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) LRAC continuously declines—economies of scale at all outputs. b) 12, 7, 5.33, 4.5, 4. c) One firm: Q≈458, P≈$4.18, LRAC≈$4.18. d) Two firms: each LRAC≈$6.37. e) Yes, natural monopoly—one firm has lower cost than multiple firms.
worked_examples.concept_applied: A natural monopoly exists when one firm can produce the entire market output at lower average cost than multiple firms. This occurs with continuously declining LRAC.

summary: In the long run, all inputs are variable, and there are no fixed costs. The long-run average cost (LRAC) curve shows the lowest possible average cost for each output level when the firm can choose any scale of operation. LRAC is typically U-shaped: falling due to economies of scale, possibly flat due to constant returns, then rising due to diseconomies of scale. Economies of scale (increasing returns to scale) occur when average cost falls as output increases, caused by specialization, technological factors, and bulk buying. Diseconomies of scale (decreasing returns to scale) occur when average cost rises as output increases, caused by coordination problems, bureaucracy, and communication difficulties. The LRAC curve is the envelope of all possible short-run average total cost (SRATC) curves—each SRATC represents a different plant size, and LRAC touches each at the output where that plant size is optimal. Minimum efficient scale (MES) is the smallest output at which LRAC reaches its minimum. MES relative to market demand determines market structure: small MES leads to competitive industries; large MES leads to oligopoly or natural monopoly. Understanding long-run costs is essential for analyzing firm growth, industry structure, and antitrust policy.
